The NAFTA agreement is just one piece of a large and continually unfolding documentary describing the dismantling of a manufacturing based economy. It started rearing it's ugly head in the late 70's with Japan and Korea challenging domestic auto makers and the heavy equipment industry. Electronics, tools, textiles soon followed and Taiwan entered the import arena. Today, it's hard to pick up anything that isn't made in China. Frankly, as for Mexico impacting our economy, I think the illegal alien problem has cost us more than the importing of goods manufactured across the border. Labor unions, litigation, and governmental controls have made the United States an unlikely choice for anyone looking to set up a manufacturing plant.

A flip of the switch in BC or Quebec would leave millions, likely 10s of millions, without electricity. The distribution and price of this power is tightly controlled by NAFTA.
 
 Our natural gas is pipelined directly to Chicago, at prices guaranteed and controlled by NAFTA.
